This procedure document supplements the Policy for the Management of Incidents and Serious Incidents (SIs) to provide staff with clear guidance on how to respond to, report, manage and investigate incidents, including serious incidents.

This procedure applies to all Mid and South Essex (MSE) NHS Foundation Trust staff, including volunteers and those employed on a bank, agency or locum basis and should be read in conjunction with the Policy for the Management of Incidents and Serious Incidents (SIs).
The procedure applies to all types of incidents including near misses whether clinical or non-clinical which could affect patients, employees or the public and/or the organisation.
Implementation of this procedure does not replace the personal responsibilities of staff with regard to issues of professional accountability.

A process map is provided in Appendix A to assist all staff reporting or investigating an incident. Should the incident be identified as a potential serious incident, the process described in Appendix B will be implemented by ward/department managers.
Immediate response following an incident or near miss event
The needs of patients and their family / carers must be made the first priority.

In all instances, the first priority of anyone involved in an incident is to ensure the needs of individuals affected are attended to, including any urgent clinical care that may reduce the harmful impact. The risk of recurrence should be considered immediately and actions taken to mitigate such a risk in advance of any investigation.

A safe environment must be re-established, all equipment or medication quarantined, labelled and isolated, and all relevant documentation copied and secured to preserve evidence to facilitate the investigation and learning. To maintain product liability, no piece of equipment should be returned to the manufacturer for repair/examination until the Trust has carried out all necessary tests on the equipment as suggested by the MHRA.
If required measurements, drawings or photographs of the location of the incident should be taken.
The incident should be reported via incident reporting system.

The line manager should be informed so they are able to determine if there are any potential risks that need to be assessed, and can provide good oversight of any problems that require senior support. This may include considering whether staff are able to continue on their shift.

If there is a suggestion that a criminal offence has been committed, the Police must be contacted. Staff should be prepared to provide statements and line managers should provide support. The template for completing a written statement can be found on the intranet.

Consideration should be made as to whether the incident may meet the threshold for a safeguarding referral, including neglect, willful neglect and acts of omission. Refer to safeguarding guidance and the Safeguarding Teams for further advice.
If in doubt as to what to do:
Escalate your concerns to your immediate line manager
If they are not available or it is not appropriate, go to the next level until you find someone who is able to help
Speak to a member of the Patient Safety Team
Remember – incident reporting and preventing harm is essential
and the Trust operates an ‘open and just' culture.
When you have been informed by your staff that there has been an incident you should undertake the following actions:

If the incident is a potential serious incident, notification must be made to the appropriate Divisional / Clinical Director or other member of the Senior Management Team (SMT), and the Patient Safety Team.
Out of hours (17:01 – 08:59) the Clinical Site Manager should be contacted via the switchboard where immediate operational action to maintain patient safety is required.
Staff concerns

4.2.1 Where a serious incident raises concerns in relation to an individual's capability or competence, the staff member must be treated with care and consideration and supported within the principles of a ‘just culture'.

4.2.2 Staff involved or affected by the incident should be supported in line with the Support for staff policy and the just culture guide published by NHS Improvement. The just culture guide can be found in the Policy for the management of incidents and serious incidents (SIs).
Multi-agency serious incidents

4.3.1 Where more than one site within the MSE group is involved in a serious incident, the Directors of Nursing and or Medical Directors will review the details to determine the lead organisation and ensure appropriate support from each site.

4.3.2 Where more than one organisation is involved in a serious incident, the relevant commissioner will be responsible for deciding who will act as the lead organisation for the purposes of investigation and incident management, and be responsible for reporting the incident. The Patient Safety Team will liaise with the Clinical Commissioning Group and advise accordingly.
Reporting the incident – local level

The Trust uses an electronic incident management system (IMS) for the reporting and management of all incidents. Managers of all service areas must have arrangements in place to ensure this policy is implemented in their areas. This includes ensuring that all members of staff have received the training to enable them to identify and report incidents.

Appendix C sets out the process and timescales for reporting an identified incident. All incidents must be reported directly after all immediate actions have been taken to maintain safety of patients, members of the public and staff.

Any member of staff can complete an electronic incident report for incidents and near misses involving them, a colleague, a patient, visitor or contractor, or any other person or agency affected by the Trust's activities.

data.text: Documenting an incident in the healthcare records

The details of a reported patient safety incident must be recorded contemporaneously and objectively within the patient's individual healthcare record including the incident number generated from the reporting system. Incident forms however are a management document and copies must not be filed in clinical records.

Incident reports are disclosable documents in the event of a claim against the Trust. It is therefore essential that facts only, not opinions, are documented. It should be noted that completion of an incident form does not constitute an admission of liability of any kind.
Incident review – quality assurance

All reported patient safety incidents are reviewed daily. If an incident is identified as a potential a Serious Incident, then an Initial Management Review (IMR) form should be completed within 48 hours and submitted for review at the next scheduled Executive Review Group.
Investigating the incident – local level
Those with responsibility for the investigation and closure of incidents must ensure that the following is undertaken and evidenced within the incident report:
Appropriate follow-up to the incident;
Investigation at the appropriate level;
Any required additional actions to maintain patient safety;
Satisfactory closure of the incident.
8.1.3 Incomplete incident forms and incidents ‘open' beyond the agreed timescale for investigation will be identified and reported back to the Senior Management Teams of the relevant Division.

8.1.4 Please note that failure to comply with the standard timescale for investigating and closing incidents is 20 working days and will form part of the Divisional / Directorate Performance and Accountability framework.
Further Information Requests – Quality Assurance

All patient safety incidents are reviewed daily by the divisional / directorate manager / coordinators / facilitators and independently by the Patient Safety Team to quality assure the content, grading and identification of incidents in the correct location. As part of this process if an incident does not provide sufficient detail then a request will be made for further information to the Division and/or reporter – this request must be answered within 48 working hours to avoid any delay.
External alerts to be raised by the Trust

8.3.1 NHS Care providers have a duty to alert other organisations to any incidents identified that could or have put a patients safety at risk or compromised their on-going care to enable continuous learning and promote patient safety.
8.3.2 Staff should report all incidents which are identified as occurring whilst the patient was under the care of an external organisation via the Trust's Incident Management System.

8.3.3 The Divisional / Directorate should determine whether completion of an External Incident Alert form is required and if so attach this to the Incident Management System detailing the secure email address of the recipient. The Patient Safety Team should be advised to allow the alert to be securely sent to the appropriate organisation.

8.3.4 Consideration should be made as to whether the incident may meet the threshold for a safeguarding referral to the Local Authority, including neglect, willful neglect and acts of omission. Refer to safeguarding guidance and the Safeguarding Teams for further advice. If the incident is deemed appropriate for a Section 42 Safeguarding Enquiry, the Safeguarding Team will advise on how the Enquiry can be answered without undertaking a separate investigation / report.
Reporting potential serious incidents (SI's)

All staff (directly or through their line managers) must notify their Divisional / Directorate senior leadership team and the Patient Safety Team of unexpected deaths and all other serious incidents or potential serious occurs as soon as possible after the event. The Divisional Senior Management Team should ensure that the Patient Safety Team is contacted via email.
Timescales for the process of completing SI investigations, reporting and action plans can be found at Appendix C.

Once an incident has been identified as a potential Serious Incident an Initial Management Review (IMR) form must be completed, normally within 48 working hours of the incident being identified, to allow presentation at the next scheduled Executive Review Group.

Discussion at the Executive Review Group will determine whether any further investigation is required and if so what level of investigation is indicated. This process is managed by the Patient Safety Team.

If a serious incident or Never Event occurs that has impacted on patient safety out of hours, during a weekend or bank holiday, the on call Clinical Site Manager must be contacted immediately by the person in charge of the area where the incident occurred. The on call Clinical Site Manager will be responsible for informing the On Call Manager who will in turn inform the On Call Director, where required. Communication must be sent to the Patient Safety Team to ensure appropriate follow up in hours.
Never events
Never Events are a particular type of serious incident that meet the following criteria:

They are considered entirely preventable, where guidance or safety recommendations that provide strong systemic protective barriers are available at a national level, and should have been implemented by all healthcare providers.

Each Never Event type has the potential to cause serious patient harm or death. However, serious harm or death is not required to have happened as a result of a specific incident occurrence for that incident to be categorised as a Never Event.

Staff involved in Never Events must be fully supported in line with all other serious incident processes. All documentation related to the Never Event must have the wording clearly marked for ease of reference.
Once a Never Event has been confirmed the requirements of the Never event escalation process will be met. Please refer to Appendix E.
Local post-incident reporting – initial review for serious
incidents (SIs)

The Divisional / Directorate Senior Management Team will ensure that the Initial Management Review (IMR) is produced as soon as possible and ideally within 24 hours where an incident is considered a potential SI but within 48 hours. This will be completed by a person with appropriate skill and responsibility in the area where the potential serious incident occurred. The person completing the IMR will be identified by the Division / Directorate.
11.1.1 The report should be submitted to the Patient Safety Team for quality assurance. If approved, the IMR will then be added to the agenda for the next Executive Review Group.

11.1.2 The IMR decision sheet will be updated with the outcome of the Executive Review Group meeting by the Patient Safety Team as a 72hour report for submission to the Commissioners within 3 days of declaration.
Safeguarding incidents – children or adults at risk

11.2.1 If the incident is a potential adult or child Safeguarding concern, the member of staff should ensure this is reported in accordance with the Trust's Safeguarding Policy and Procedures. In hours the relevant Safeguarding Lead/Named Nurse must be contacted for appropriate guidance and support. Out of hours the On Call Clinical Site Manager must be contacted.
11.2.2 In all incidences of a potential Safeguarding concern then an incident form must be raised ensuring that the category is identified as Safeguarding.
Incidents of fraud or suspected fraud

11.3.1 In the event of fraudulent or suspected fraudulent activity, the Local Counter Fraud Specialist is to be notified immediately. The LCFS will liaise with the regional Area Anti-Fraud Specialist and NHS Counter Fraud Authority and in conjunction with the Chief Finance Officer will decide who will conduct the investigation and when/if referral to the Police is required.
11.3.2 Please refer to the Trust's Counter Fraud policy for additional guidance on how to report and manage this category of incident.
Incidents of violence and aggression

11.4.1 Any incident of verbal abuse towards staff or where physical contact was made with a member of staff in a violent or aggressive manner must be reported, including incidents where the clinical condition of a patient may be a factor. Please refer to the relevant site Security Management and Violence and Aggression policies for further guidance regarding security management and management of violence risks.
Incidents involving the restraint of patients

11.5.1 All incidents where patients have been physically or chemically restrained must be reported and reviewed, and a decision made as whether the incident meets the thresh hold for further investigation.
11.5.2 The Department of Health Document “Positive and Proactive Care: reducing the need for restrictive interventions” (2014) defines restrictive as:
Deliberate acts on the part of other person(s) that restrict an individual's movement, liberty and / or freedom to act independently in order to:
Take immediate control of a dangerous situation where there is a real possibility of harm to the person or other if no action is undertaken: and
End or reduce significantly the danger to the person or others; and
Contain or limit the persons freedom for no longer than is necessary

11.5.3 Chemical restraint is the use of medication which is prescribed and administered for the purpose of controlling or subduing violent behaviour, where it is not prescribed for the treatment of a formally identified physical or mental illness.
11.5.4 The following questions will be addressed within the investigation which will be completed on the Internal Investigation form:
What was the nature of the aggressive behaviour displayed by the patient that necessitated restraint?
What was risk if patient had not been restrained?
Had any alternatives been attempted prior to restraining patient?
Was restraining the patient the only option in the circumstances?
What type of restraint was applied? For how long?
Medication incidents including those involving controlled drugs
11.6.1 The Medication Safety Officer (MSO) can provide advice and support on how to manage and share the learning from medication incidents.

11.6.2 Discrepancies in controlled drug balance. The healthcare professional who finds the error should conduct the initial investigation. If the omission or error can be traced, then the nurse in charge should make an entry in controlled drug register stating reason for error and corrected balance. This needs to be witnessed by doctor, another registered nurse or pharmacy staff. If error cannot be explained then this needs to be reported immediately to pharmacist/NPT, ward manager and Accountable officer.
(Refer to Controlled Drugs policy for further details)
Information Governance Incidents

11.7.1 Serious data loss / incidents related to breach of confidentiality will be reported as risk events but the investigation will follow the Information Governance Toolkit Incident Reporting Tool and will be overseen / managed by the Trust SIRO, Caldicott Guardian and Information Governance Manager.
Being open and Duty of Candour

There is a contractual and legislated responsibility of all healthcare organisations to be open and transparent with patients and their families when things go wrong with care delivery. This forms the basic principle of Being Open and Duty of Candour.

If an incident is suspected to have caused moderate or severe harm, or death, the Duty of Candour must be met. Please refer to the Being Open and Duty of Candour policy for further guidance. If staff are unsure whether Duty of Candour should be undertaken, please contact the Patient Safety Team who can provide further advice and guidance.

It is essential that staff who communicate such information to patients and/or relatives ensure that appropriate support is provided to them and also to any staff involved in the incident. Further support can be obtained from the Patient Safety Team during working hours, or via the Clinical Site Manager out of hours.
Internal incident investigation – not a SI
The lead IO will complete an internal investigation report.
The report must be completed within 7 working days of the request being made at ERG.

The report must be approved by the Division and submitted with a Divisional Checklist (Appendix D) to the Patient Safety Team for quality assurance. If the report is considered to be fit for purpose, it will be scheduled for submission to the Investigation Review Panel (IRP). Investigating Officers will present their report and findings to the IRP who will make recommendations for approval to the ERG.

It falls to the Division / Directorate leadership teams to ensure that the recommendations identified within the internal Investigation reports are actioned, with associated evidence. This evidence must be uploaded directly onto the incident management system.
Investigating the serious incident
Lead Investigating Officer (IO) responsibilities

14.1.1 An appropriately trained lead Investigating Officer (IO) will be appointed by the relevant Division / Directorate. In addition, an Action Plan Lead should also be identified to support the IO in developing the action plan. The IO must have received their training in Root Cause Analysis.
If no training has been received then the member of staff cannot be the lead IO. However, they may form part of the investigation team to provide bespoke support.

data.url: MSEPO-19015 Procedure report management of incidents and serious incidents 1.3.004.png

data.text: 14.1.2 The lead IO will be supported in clarifying the scope and terms of reference for the investigation. The terms of reference should be agreed at an initial meeting attended by the Patient Safety Team and Divisional facilitator.

14.1.3 The lead IO should ideally form a team of appropriately qualified and experienced individuals to provide expert advice or support to the investigation. The lead IO will have support from the Divisional / Directorate governance staff and an appropriate member of the Patient Safety Team throughout the investigation.

14.1.4 The Divisional Governance staff will ensure that appropriate records and evidence are retained centrally and securely, and advise the lead IO on all stages of the SI investigation process. This will include ensuring the clinical records and any evidence are secured at the earliest opportunity, and that the relevant section of the clinical record is copied and made available to the lead IO.
Serious incident investigation
14.2.1 The IO will undertake a full Root Cause Analysis (RCA) investigation and compile a report using the Trust Serious Incident Investigation template.
14.2.2 Wherever possible, the lead IO will communicate with the patient/family/carer at the outset of the investigation, inviting them to contribute to the terms of reference.
14.2.3 In addition to the report, the lead IO must provide the following documents in support of the investigation findings and conclusions:
All statements received from those involved in the incident and investigation;
Any other supporting evidence used as part of the investigation;
A record of any meetings conducted during the investigation supported by the Divisional Governance staff;
A detailed chronology of the incident;
All completed RCA tools used to establish contributory factors and root
cause(s).
14.2.4 All associated documents must be scanned and attached to the incident report on the Incident Management System.
Requests to provide witness statements in relation to incident investigations and inquests

14.3.1 When a potential serious incident has occurred the manager responsible for the area where the incident occurred should make arrangements for all staff to document their recollection of the incident in the Trust statement format.

14.3.2 This statement will be important as part of the root cause analysis investigation. If this has not occurred, then the Lead IO should formally request these as soon as possible at the start of the investigative process.

14.3.3 There may however be circumstances where formal, signed statements are required from staff such as when required by an external body such as HM Coroner or the Police. Staff must immediately direct all correspondence in relation to inquests or potential claims for compensation to the Litigation Department, without responding. This includes any request received by a member of staff directly from HM Coroner, Coroner's Officer or Police to provide information relating to an inquest. The Legal Team will advise staff on the course of action to be followed.
Action plan preparation
14.4.1 The Lead IO must work with the divisional / service action plan lead (APL) to compile a comprehensive action plan that addresses the recommendations developed within the investigation report.
14.4.2 The action plan must include details of how the lessons learnt from the investigation will be shared.
Reporting deadlines

14.5.1 The Lead IO must present their report and associated action plan, to the Divisional / Directorate / Clinical Director, Head of Nursing / Midwifery / Associate Directors of Nursing and / or Service lead to share their findings and for the Divisional management team to agree the report and action plan.

14.5.2 The agreed report must be sent to the Patient Safety Team within 40 working days. To support presentation at the IRP, the Division must submit a Divisional Checklist with the report (Appendix D).

14.5.3 The draft report will then be quality assured by a designated member of the Patient Safety Team. Further questions and/or information will be addressed directly to the Lead IO, with the Divisional / Directorate Governance staff kept informed to provide support where required.

14.5.4 Once all questions have been satisfactorily answered, and the report has been quality assured as meeting the required standard, the Division will be informed and the report submitted to the next scheduled Investigation Review Panel (IRP). The Division will present the report before a site Medical Director and/or site Director of Nursing for approval.

14.5.5 Once approved by the IRP, a recommendation for approval by the Executive Review Group will be made and the report shared with Commissioners for review and approval via secure email transfer. The mandated requirement for the report to be with the Commissioners is 60 working days.

14.5.6 Additional questions from the Commissioners will be managed through the Patient Safety Team; ensuring information governance standards are met – the turnaround time for this process is set at 20 working days. It is imperative that any questions asked are addressed as soon as possible and divisional governance group so that opportunities for learning can be optimised.
14.5.7 The lead IO is expected to conduct the investigation in line with the timescales set out in Appendix C.
Distributing reports post approval

14.6.1 Following ERG, the approved report will be sent to the Divisional / Directorate leadership team for dissemination. It is the responsibility of the Division to ensure that the Patient or family receive a copy of the approved report in line with the Trust's Being Open and Duty of Candour policy. This should ideally be sent by the Divisional / Clinical Director or Head of Nursing/Midwifery / Associate Directors of Nursing and/or Service lead or lead clinician and as soon as reasonably practicable after the approval of the report.
14.6.2 The approved report should be shared with all staff involved in the investigation and with other relevant Divisions to ensure that lessons are learnt across the organisation or group.
14.6.3 Root Cause Analysis reports for Maternity serious incidents will be shared with the Board via the Maternity Assurance Group in advance of the meeting.
After action review

Organisational learning requires continuous assessment of organisational performance, looking at successes and failures, ensuring that learning takes place to support continuous improvement. The After Action Review (AAR) is a simple option for facilitating this assessment. It works by bringing together a team to discuss a task, event, activity or project, in an open and honest fashion.

The systematic application of properly conducted AARs across an organisation can help drive organisational change. As well as turning unconscious learning into tacit, it helps to build trust among team members and to overcome fear of mistakes. When applied correctly, AARs can become a key aspect of the internal system of learning and motivation.

There are many different ways to conduct AARs. The simplicity at the heart of the tool means there is much potential to experiment with the process and find the right ways that will work best with the group and the work item under

review. The whole process should be kept as simple and as easy to remember as possible. The essence of the AAR is, however, to bring together the relevant group to think about a project, activity, event or task, and pose the following simple questions.

If a Serious Incident has been declared then an AAR must be considered. An appropriately trained facilitator should be sought to aid participants in a ‘blame free' environment, designed to answer the key questions during the process. Further support can be found from the Patient Safety Team.
The IO should be included as an observer only in this process to aid in the investigation.

table_items.text: What was supposed to happen? What actually happened? Why were there differences?

These questions establish a common understanding of the work item under review. The facilitator should encourage and promote discussion around these questions. In particular, divergences from the plan should be explored.
These questions generate reflection about the
successes and failures during the course of
the project, activity, event or task. The
question ‘Why?' generates understanding of the root causes of these successes and failures.
What would you do differently next time?
This question is intended to help identify specific actionable recommendations. The facilitator asks the team members for crisp and clear, achievable and future-oriented recommendations.

data.text: Action plans

It is the responsibility of the senior leads for area where the incident occurred to implement and monitor the actions arising from an incident, co- ordinated by the Action Plan Lead (APL). Exceptions to this would be where the required changes involve more than one division and are considered to be a joint responsibility across Divisions or may be considered to be Corporate. This will be clear from the allocation of responsibilities within the action plan.
Tracking and assuring actions
16.2.1 Internal Incident Investigations

Recommendations are the responsibility of the Division / Directorate where the incident occurred and the changes need to take place. Divisional / clinical governance arrangements must describe the process whereby these recommendations are evidenced. These must be captured and reported onto the Incident Management system administered by the Divisional Governance staff. As a minimum the Patient Safety Team will conduct periodic reviews of Internal Incident investigations recommendations to test the effectiveness of these arrangements, including scrutiny of evidence in support of the actions.
16.2.2 Serious Incident Investigations

Whilst implementation of the actions following serious incident investigations lies at a divisional level, it is the responsibility of the Patient Safety Team to provide a tracking system for these action plans.

Divisions/departments are expected to provide regular updates on their achievement against any serious incident action plan, highlighting where actions are overdue or non-achievement of deadlines is anticipated, providing assurance evidence when actions are reported as ‘complete'.

The designated APL will oversee action plans until all actions are completed with the appropriate assurance evidence available to the Patient Safety Team through the Incident Management System. The nominated action leads, as indicated through the action plan, will be requested to deliver their action(s) within the timescales agreed.

The Divisional / Directorate Governance staff are responsible for providing monthly progress reports on the status of actions arising from serious incidents. Delivery of actions will be monitored at the appropriate local governance group and Risk and Compliance group meeting.

Overall responsibility for this process lies with the management team where the incident occurred. In the event that actions cannot be completed within the given timescale this must be escalated to the divisional management team in accordance with the Trust's risk management framework at the earliest opportunity, and recorded on the appropriate risk register.

It is the responsibility of the divisional senior management team to ensure that learning from serious incidents is shared with appropriate staff groups, and that recommendations following such incidents are acted on.

Once the division consider all actions associated with a serious incident have been completed they will be invited to present the action plan to the Investigation Review Panel. The IRP will in turn make a recommendation for closure to the Executive Review Group.
The Executive Assurance Group has been established to oversee action plan closures to assess whether additional quality improvement initiatives are indicated.
Bespoke investigation reports
Tissue viability/pressure ulcers

17.1.1 All pressure ulcers identified on admission and those that develop while in hospital must be assessed, recorded, photographed and incident reported and the appropriate investigation initiated into identifying the root cause for those deemed to have occurred while in hospital. Consideration should be given to raising a safeguarding alert for ulcers identified on admission.

17.1.2 When a hospital-acquired pressure ulcer has been identified the relevant Pressure Ulcer Root Cause Analysis template should be completed. These must be conducted for all category 2, 3 and 4 hospital acquired pressure ulcers and deep tissue injuries.

17.1.3 The first five sections of the report are expected to be completed within 7 working days. The report should be sent through to the Patient Safety Team or quality assurance and of appropriate added to the agenda of the Harm Free Group. This group meets weekly and representation from the relevant Ward (at Ward Manager level) is expected, along with relevant Matron support. At this point any causal lapses in adherence to protocols will be identified and the following decisions will be made:
Category 2 with lapses in care – this will require all actions to be completed from Section 5 of the report.

Category 3 or 4 / deep tissue injury with lapses in care – this will require the final sections of the RCA to be completed in line with NHS England guidelines for the investigation of Serious Incidents. Dependent on the level of harm to the patient , these reports may then be sent through to the Commissioners in line with standard SI investigation timescales.

Category 2/3/4/ with no lapses in care – this will require all actions to be completed from Section 5 of the report and to assure that wider learning occurs through appropriate communication channels.
Falls resulting in harm

17.2.1 Any fall that occurs in hospital that results in harm has the potential to be a Serious Incident. The initial sections of the bespoke Falls Root Cause Analysis Template must be completed. These must be received within 7 working days so they can be reviewed at the Harm Free Group. The following decisions will be made:

Non Complaint with pathway fall – this will require the final sections of the RCA to be completed in line with NHS England guidelines for the investigation of Serious Incidents. Depending on the impact for the patient these reports may then be sent through to the Commissioners in line with standard SI investigation timescales.
Compliant with pathway fall - this will require all actions to be completed from Section 5 of the report and to assure that wider learning occurs through appropriate communication channels.

Please note: All falls that result in fracture and/or head injury that have led to severe harm to the patient will be immediately classified as a Serious Incident. For patients that die following a fall the Serious Incident Investigation will be completed on the comprehensive SI template.
Healthcare associated infections (HCAI) investigations

17.3.1 From April 2013 the guidance on the reporting and monitoring arrangements for MRSA blood stream infections (MRSA BSI), changed. It is considered unacceptable for a patient to acquire an MRSA bloodstream infection while receiving care in a healthcare setting.

17.3.2 In order to support providers of care to deliver a zero tolerance approach on MRSA BSI there is a requirement to instigate a Post Infection Review (PIR). This process replaces the requirement to undertake Root Cause Analysis. The aim of the PIR is to identify how a case occurred and identify the actions that will prevent it from recurring. It must be conducted by a multidisciplinary clinical team that will review the case and the contributing factors.

17.3.3 The outcome of the PIR will be to attribute responsibility for the case, and relies on strong partnership working by all providers involved in the care of the patient. When a case occurs more than 48 hours after admission this is considered to be ‘hospital acquired and the PIR process will be led and managed by the Trust's Infection Prevention and Control team. At the PIR multi-disciplinary review meeting if a case is preventable and there has been harm to a patient this will be escalated to ERG as a serious incident.
Venous thromboembolism (VTE)

17.4.1 All incidents of suspected hospital acquire VTEs will have a bespoke RCA template sent to the Division / Directorate for completion. Once completed by the Division, this will be reviewed for a decision at Executive Review Group. All hospital acquired VTEs with lapses in care will be declared as serious incidents and require investigation by an independent investigating officer.
Learning from incidents
Learning lessons

18.1.1 One of the key aims of the serious incident reporting and learning process is to reduce the risk of recurrence. The timely and appropriate dissemination of learning following an SI is core to achieving this and to ensure that these lessons are embedded in practice.
Definition of learning in the context of patient safety
18.2.1 Learning from a patient safety incident should be a collaborative, decentralised and reflective process that draws on experience, knowledge and evidence from a variety of sources.
Organisational learning can be demonstrated by sustainable changes and improvements in process, policy, systems and procedures relating to patient safety.
Individual learning can be demonstrated by sustainable changes and improvements in behavior, beliefs, and attitudes and knowledge of workers at the front line of service delivery.
Examples of learning
18.3.1 Examples of learning following a patient safety related incident include:
Rapid response actions to reduce immediate threats to safety ensure that staff remain engaged and understand that their reports are being taken seriously.
Changes such as to tools/equipment/working environment/standard working procedures/training programmes/audit process.
Strengthening systems and processes that allow early detection or intervention that will reduce the potential impact of future incidents.
Documenting the identification of the risks, the extent to which they have been reduced, and how this is measured and monitored.
Identification of the components of good practice that reduced the potential impact of the incident, and how they were developed and supported.

Sharing solutions to address identified incident root causes and contributory factors that may be relevant to other teams, services or organisations – within local work systems and across the organisation, as appropriate.
Disseminating learning

18.4.1 There are a number of ways in which learning from a serious or critical incident might be disseminated within the Trust to raise safety awareness and reduce the risk of recurrence. Examples of communication methods include:
Visible leadership support at ward, divisional / directorate and corporate level.
Meetings with patients and their families.
Presentations at safety huddles or staff meetings.
E-bulletins and newsletters
Intranet site.
Public board papers.
Patient safety notice boards.
E-mail.
Internal patient safety alerts.
Reports to safety and quality or governance forums or committees
Incorporation into risk management, incident reporting and investigation training i.e. using case studies.
Performance management review meetings.
Assurance mechanisms.
Annual quality reporting arrangements.
Local conferences, seminars and workshops.
Periodic serious incident and incident summary reports.
Educational meetings including the Grand Round.
Incident closure
19.1.1 The criteria for judging that an incident can be ‘closed' will be proportionate to the grade of the incident.
19.1.2 In addition a response must be sent to the reporter to show what action has been taken to assure them of appropriate incident investigation.
Actions required to close Internal Investigations and Serious Incidents
19.2.1 Where the incident is judged as requiring either an Internal or Serious Incident Investigation then the following actions must be evidenced before a Serious Incident can be closed:
All Serious Incident Investigations:
Care and Service Delivery Problems
Contributory Factors
Lessons Learned
Root Causes
Recommendations
Internal Incident investigation:
Serious Incident investigation:
Monitoring compliance with this procedure
Compliance with these procedures is monitored on an ongoing basis by the Patient Safety Team
Regular review of key performance indicators at divisional / directorate governance meetings and senior leadership team meetings ensures there is senior oversight.
